docs.lead_paragraph: The power brokers obsessed with tort reform really have the jargon down. They travel the country with overheated stories about runaway juries and jackpot justice. The way they tell it, sinister lawyers and opportunistic plaintiffs are on the hunt, preying on virtuous corporations, hospitals and doctors in search of that big payout from the lawsuit lottery. President Bush has been complaining about ''junk and frivolous'' lawsuits for years. So it's interesting to hear the following from the Center for Justice and Democracy, a consumer advocacy group:
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column lists some malpractice myths; says Center for Justice and Democracy, consumer advocacy group, finds that tort filings are declining, only 2 percent of injured people sue for compensation, punitive damages are rarely awarded, liability insurance costs for businesses are miniscule, medical malpractice insurance and claims are both less than 1 percent of all health care costs in America and premium-gouging underwriting practices of insurance industry have been widely exposed; notes that insurance industry executives are careful not to say that tort reforms sought by Bush administration will result in premium reductions; says this is all about greed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New accounting standards will require state and local governments to acknowledge the full cost of health benefits promised to retirees, putting immense pressure on public employers to reduce their liabilities by scaling back benefits or shifting more of the cost to retirees, government officials and accountants say. Supporters say the rules will help state and local officials, investors and taxpayers understand the magnitude of these commitments to current and future retirees.

headline.main: Rules to Expose Long-Term Cost Of Health Plans

docs.abstract: New accounting standards will require state and local governments to acknowledge full cost of health benefits promised to retirees, putting pressure on public employers to reduce their liabilities by scaling back benefits or shifting more of cost to retirees; public employees predict that rules, developed by independent, nonprofit Governmental Accounting Standards Board, combined with soaring cost of health care, will speed erosion of health insurance in public sector, as happened at many private companies decade ago; rules apply to all state and local governments; under current practice, most public employers do not report such costs until they pay for promised benefits, often many years after employees have retired; experts on employee benefits say new standards would encourage state and local officials to set aside money in trust funds for purpose of providing health benefits to retirees; cost of such contributions would be new, immediate expense for state and local governments already struggling with severe financial problems (M)
docs.snippet: New accounting standards will require state and local governments to acknowledge the full cost of health benefits promised to retirees, putting immense pressure on public employers to reduce their liabilities by scaling back benefits or shifting more...

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN heading out for a night on the town, Bill, a writer from Boston, always grabs the same things: his wallet, two condoms and a Viagra. But Bill is not a middle-aged guy with erectile dysfunction. He is 26. ''I like how it makes me feel, it gives me more power,'' said Bill, who, like most of the men interviewed for this article, did not want his last name used. ''It's like I'm taking something to make a good thing better.''

headline.main: Party Favors: Pill Popping As Insurance

docs.abstract: Younger men who take erectile dysfunction pills as party drugs have turned pills into form of currency in certain circles, including gays and some college students (special section, Men's Health) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York State's leaders are poised to formally end the 2004 legislative session on Tuesday without passing the budget that was due April 1, without complying with a court order requiring them to come up with a plan to send more money to New York City's schools, and without enacting any major new laws. Even for a state government that has become better known in recent years for inaction than for accomplishment, elected officials and governmental analysts of all stripes say that the lack of achievement so far this year represents another low for Albany. After top officials conceded that they would not have a budget before the recess, their staffs began frantic negotiations in the hope that lawmakers, whose seats are all up for election in November, could announce that they had done something by Tuesday.

headline.main: Albany Legislature Set to Adjourn Without Doing Much Legislating

docs.abstract: New York State's leaders will formally end 2004 legislative session without passing budget that was due Apr 1, without complying with court order to develop plan to send more money to New York City's schools and without enacting any major news laws; lack of achievement so far this year represents another low for state government in Albany better known in recent years for inaction than for accomplishment; Gov George E Pataki and Legislature leaders Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and Sen majority leader Joseph L Bruno agree that session has been 'abysmal'; before leaving town, lawmakers will vote to approve temporary spending bill from Pataki to keep government running until Aug; list of unfinished business is long and impact on public is real; partial listing of programs that have not been financed yet (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BACK in 1979, when he was battling the scourge of double-digit inflation, Paul A. Volcker often remarked that part of his job was psychological. ''Inflation feeds in part on itself, so part of the job of returning to a more stable and productive economy must be to break the grip of inflationary expectations,'' said Mr. Volcker, who was chairman of the Federal Reserve from 1979 to 1987. He ultimately did slay the dragon, but only after administering some of the harshest economic medicine -- interest rates as high as 18 percent -- that Americans have ever seen.

headline.main: A Fight Against Fear As Well as Inflation

docs.abstract: Federal Reserve is agains wrestling with inflationary expections as it gears up to raise interest rates; Chmn Alan Greenspan and other top officials have been both saying that inflationary pressures are not likely to be serious concern and warning that they will move more aggressively to cool economy if inflation becomes threat; graph of real federal funds rate (M)a

docs.lead_paragraph: Emergency medical crews on the East End raised objections last week to a Suffolk County legislative proposal that would require them to respond to all calls within nine minutes, saying it would be impossible because of the large area they cover. Edward A. Seltenreich, chief of the East Quogue Fire Department, said said it took the all-volunteer department three to six minutes to get one of its two advanced life-support ambulances on the road.

headline.main: Emergency Medical Crews Object to Response Time

docs.abstract: Emergency medical crews object to Suffolk County legislative proposal that would require them to respond to all calls within nine minutes or face not being covered under county's liability insurance (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Falling in the polls and with his attack advertisements apparently backfiring, Prime Minister Paul Martin was banking on two nationally televised debates this week to stop the bleeding in time for the June 28 election. But he was put on the defensive in both. The very first question from a journalist on the questioning panel of the English-language debate on Tuesday could not have been more damaging, and Mr. Martin never fully recovered.

headline.main: Canada Leader Loses Ground As Opponents Draw Closer

docs.abstract: Canadian Prime Min Paul Martin fares poorly in televised debates in advance of June 28 election; separatist Bloc Quebecois appears poised to sweep Quebec elections and New Democratic Party is doing so well in urban areas that neither main conservative nor liberal party is likely to win majority; Martin also faces unexpected threat from Conservative Stephen Harper, who has moderated rhetoric to broaden appeal; Martin's hope is that enough voters will turn away from New Democrats back to Liberals in order to stop Harper; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE latest status symbol on the East End of Long Island is as revealing as it is outrageous: priority medical treatment at Southampton Hospital for 50 wealthy families in return for a ''membership'' fee. The 95-year-old financially ailing Southampton Hospital -- the only serious medical emergency center on the South Fork -- is offering a plan aimed at wealthy summer visitors whose primary doctors are back in Manhattan and out of reach, presumably along with the hospital's sense of propriety. For $6,000 per family, or $3,800 for individuals, not including doctors' fees, cardholders in the Southampton PLUS plan are entitled to ''priority access'' to medical care at the hospital from May 28 to Sept. 26. A brochure about the plan was mailed to several thousand summer homeowners from a mailing list the hospital purchased from a source it declined to identify.
docs.abstract: WLIU radio host Steven Gaines Op-Ed article opposes PLUS plan offered by Southampton Hospital whereby 50 wealthy families, in return for 'membership fee,' are entitled to 'priority access' to medical care during summer tourist season (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than two dozen witnesses, from former cabinet secretaries to unemployed textile workers, spent hours on Friday attacking President Bush's domestic policies and no time squabbling among themselves in the last of three public hearings to help the Democratic Party write its 2004 national platform. There were no flare-ups, rude banners or angry disagreements. Not even a whisper of discontent. It was a far cry from the days when Democrats regularly savaged one another over issues like the Vietnam War, civil rights and abortion.

headline.main: Democrats Work Together to Build an Anti-Bush Platform

docs.abstract: Democrats refrain from squabbling among themselves and instead attack Pres Bush in last of three public hearings of Democratic Platform Drafting Committee in Santa Fe, NM; proposed draft will be presented to 186 members of Democratic Platform Committee on July 9, who will approve it for presentation to national convention in Boston in late July; final meeting focuses on domestic issues (M)
docs.snippet: More than two dozen witnesses, from former cabinet secretaries to unemployed textile workers, spent hours on Friday attacking President Bush's domestic policies and no time squabbling among themselves in the last of three public hearings to help the...

docs.lead_paragraph: United Airlines scrambled yesterday to revise its application for $1.6 billion in federal loan guarantees, taking advantage of an offer of another chance from the Treasury Department, even though the loan board rejected its bid a day earlier. But the unusual opportunity -- one not extended to any other airline that applied for a loan package -- ignited a political storm for United, the nation's second-largest airline behind American.

headline.main: Another Loan Chance Puts United in a Political Storm; Airline, Its Wings Clipped Twice, Is Given an Unusual Third Shot

docs.abstract: United Airlines scrambles to revise its bid for $1.6 billion in federal loan guarantees; Treasury Department's decision to let it make unusual third aid bid, chance denied other airlines, stirs political storm; Treasury official says decision came after both White House and House Speaker J Dennis Hastert spoke with Sec John W Snow; industry analysts say airline would remain financially shaky even with loan guarantees; photos (M)
